text:
As you know, the commercial industry has been under attack from
both the public and its representative in Congress and the FCC. The
latter body, under Mr, Minow’s leadership, has repeatedly indicated
that it has a responsibility and authority to concern itself with
stations’ programs. As earnest of its intention to do something about
programming, it has indicated that it will be paying increasing atten¬
tion to discrepancies between program promises and performance when
it comes to license renewals.
The result of this crackdown on station programming is that the
station manager at long last is convinced that the FCC means what it
says and is going to get tough; hence stations are belatedly becoming
very worried about how to beef up the educational content of their
scheduleso To capitalize on their concern, NAEB has just issued a
flyer calling to their attention the splendid selection of high quality
educational programs available from its tape library.
The FCC has also indicated that in considering renewals of licenses
it will pay attention to how well a station has geared its programming
to meet the needs and interests of the community it serves. They have
also indicated that in satisfying this requirement a station is not
going to be able to just "fly by the seat of its pants", be guided by
questions the director asks at the bar of the local Elks club, or use
any other quaint divining rods which have gotten them by'in the past.
In fact, this means audience surveys.
Wealthy stations in metropolitan areas have means and facilities
for carrying out such surveys; stations which happen to be situated in
communities where there are colleges and universities have help at hand.
But many stations which do not enjoy such advantages, are not in a posi-
tion to conduct studies of their audiences, particularly surveys that
are not suspect.
It occurs to me that NAEB, under the aegis of its research com¬
mittee, might set up in its Washington headquarters a national audience
survey office, which would undertake to conduct surveys for local sta¬
tions to determine the special requirements and wants of their audiences.
I can envision something like the following:
1. A full time national research director, with secretary, and
office in Washington.
2. A group of regional research directors (who might or might not
be the members of the present committee) who would organize and super¬
vise arrangements for surveys within their particular geographical area.
3. Wherever possible NAEB members and/or people on college and
university staffs would be engaged for a fee to conduct a survey for a
station in their vicinity.
4. The surveys would be conducted by educators and would use
students to do the interviewing, doorbell-pushing, or whatever.
5. Although this activity would be undertaken as a service de¬
signed to return funds to the Association, it would at the same time
provide some productive research opportunities for research people
throughout the country.
